May 17, 2003|website=Grg.org|accessdate=15 December 2017}} |align=center|F |7 October 1888 |31 December 2000 |{{ayd|1888|10|7|2000|12|31}} |Puerto Rico{{ref label|Dearroyo|c}} |United States |- |5 |Consuelo Moreno-López{{cite web |url=http://www.grg.org/Adams/L/USA.HTM |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-10-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161014211455/http://www.grg.org/Adams/L/USA.HTM |archivedate=14 October 2016 |df=dmy-all }} |align=center|F |5 February 1893 |13 November 2004 |111 years, 282 days |[[Spanish Morocco]]{{ref label|Moreno|d}} |United States |- |6 |[[Manolita Piña]] |align=center|F |24 February 1883 |11 June 1994 |111 years, 107 days |Catalonia |[[Uruguay]] |- | |Victoria de la Cruz Garcia{{Cite news|url=http://www.lasprovincias.es/comunitat/misionera-espanola-japon-20170624225657-nt_amp.html#|title=Una misionera española en Japón celebra sus 110 años tocando con castañuelas 'Que viva España'|date=2017-06-25|work=Las Provincias|access-date=2017-10-22}} |align=center|F |24 June 1907 |4 June 2018 |110 years, 345 days |Andalusia |[[Japan]] |- |7 |Elisa Cubells |align=center|F |20 August 1885 |16 November 1995 |110 years, 88 days |Catalonia |[[France]] |} a{{note|Mercado del Toro}} Mercado del Toro was born in Puerto Rico which at that time was a part of the Spanish Empire. It is now in the United States.
b{{note|Iglesias-Jordan}} Iglesias-Jordan was born in Puerto Rico which at that time was a part of the Spanish Empire. It is now in the United States.
c{{note|Dearroyo}} Dearroyo was born in Puerto Rico which at that time was a part of the Spanish Empire. It is now in the United States.
d{{note|Moreno}} Moreno was born in Spanish Morocco which was a part of the [[Spanish Empire]]. It is now in [[Morocco]].
 ==People== ===Galo Leoz=== Galo Leoz Ortín (22 April 1879 – 23 January 1990) was a [[Spain|Spanish]] [[supercentenarian]] and [[oldest people|Spain's oldest recognized living person]] when he died aged 110 years 276 days. He became Spain's oldest recognized male ever when he surpassed Aurelio Diaz. Leoz's record was surpassed in 1993 by Josep Armengol Jover (23 July 1881 – 20 January 1994), who lived to the age of 112 years 181 days. Galo Leoz was a noted ophthalmologist.{{cite web|url=http://elpais.com/diario/1990/01/25/agenda/633222001_850215.html|title=Galo Leoz, el oftalmólogo de mayor edad del mundo|first=Ediciones El|last=País|date=25 January 1990|website=Elpais.com|accessdate=15 December 2017}} ===Manuela Fernández-Fojaco=== Manuela Fernández Fojaco (18 June 1895 – 6 January 2009) was the fifth-oldest living person, the oldest person in Europe and the oldest living person in Spain at the time of her death, at the age of 113 years, 202 days. Manuela Fernández Fojaco was born in Llamas, in the municipality of [[Aller, Asturias]]. On 2 January 2009, she became the oldest living European after the death of 115-year-old Portuguese woman Maria de Jesus. Her reign lasted for 4 days until her death on 6 January 2009. After her death, 112-year-old Lucia Lauria Vigna from Italy became Europe's oldest person (although [[Eugénie Blanchard]] was from [[Saint Barthélemy]], which is part of the [[European Union]]).{{cite news | url=http://www.lne.es/ultima/2009/01/07/ultima-pagina-muere-grado-abuela/713675.html | language=es | title=Grado pierde a Manuela a los 113 años | newspaper=[[La Nueva España]] | date=7 January 2009 | accessdate=4 January 2016}}{{cite news | url=http://www.lne.es/ultima/2009/01/07/mundo-quedan-supercentenarios/713676.html | language=es | title=En el mundo quedan 90 "supercentenarios" | newspaper=[[La Nueva España]] | date=7 January 2009 | accessdate=4 January 2016}} ===Ana María Vela Rubio=== Ana María Vela Rubio (29 October 1901 – 15 December 2017), aged 116 years and 47 days, was a Spanish supercentenarian who became the oldest verified Spaniard ever on 6 June 2016, when she surpassed the record of María Antonia Castro who died in 1996, aged 114 years, 220 days{{Cite web|url=http://politica.elpais.com/politica/2016/05/24/actualidad/1464108032_685941.html|title=Ana Vela se convierte a sus 114 años en la más longeva de la historia de España|language=es|date=6 June 2016|accessdate=29 October 2016}} and was also the oldest Spanish-born person from 4 April 2017 when she surpassed the record of [[Emiliano Mercado del Toro]]. At the time of her death she was the third-oldest living person in the world, behind [[Nabi Tajima]] and Chiyo Miyako. She became the oldest living European upon the death of former world's oldest person [[Emma Morano]] on 15 April 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldo.es/noticias/sociedad/2017/04/17/la-espanola-ana-vela-convierte-primera-europa-tras-muerte-emma-morano-1170439-310.html|title=La española Ana Vela se convierte en la más longeva de Europa tras la muerte de Emma Morano|first=Europa|last=Press|website=Heraldo.es|accessdate=15 December 2017}} She remains the third oldest person ever from Europe behind [[Jeanne Calment]] and Emma Morano. Vela Rubio was born in [[Puente Genil]], Andalucia. She worked as a dressmaker in her youth. She never married her partner as her parents objected to him, but the two had several children. Her daughter, also named Ana, lived with her.{{Cite web|url=http://politica.elpais.com/politica/2016/05/24/actualidad/1464108032_685941.html|title=Ana Vela se convierte a sus 114 años en la más longeva de la historia de España|language=es|date=6 June 2016|accessdate=29 October 2016}} ===Francisco Núñez Olivera=== Francisco Núñez Olivera (13 December 1904 – 29 January 2018),{{cite web|url=http://www.elmundo.es/espana/2015/04/07/5522b9fc22601d60148b4574.html|title=El hombre más longevo de España: 'Se me ha hecho la vida demasiado larga'|website=Elmundo.es|accessdate=15 December 2017}}{{cite web |url=https://www.thelocal.es/20180130/worlds-oldest-man-dies-aged-113-in-spanish-village-where-he-lived-his-whole-life |title=World's oldest man dies aged 113 in spanish village where he lived his whole life |website=The local |accessdate=29 January 2018}} aged 113 years and 47 days, was the [[oldest living man]] after the death of Polish-born Israeli [[Yisrael Kristal]] on August 11, 2017. He was born in [[Extremadura]] and joined the army at the age of 19 to fight in the [[Rif War]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thelocal.es/20160125/spaniard-is-worlds-oldest-man-or-is-he|title=This 111-year-old Spaniard is world's oldest man… or is he?|date=25 January 2016|website=Thelocal.es|accessdate=15 December 2017}} He had his kidney removed when he was 90 and a cataract operation aged 98, and was a veteran of the [[Spanish Civil War]]. He was nicknamed "Marchena" after his resemblance to native [[flamenco]] singer-songwriter/actor [[Pepe Marchena]].{{cite web|url=http://www.elperiodicoextremadura.com/noticias/provinciabadajoz/francisco-nunez-olivera-cumple-hoy-112-anos_983961.html|title=El extremeño Francisco Núñez Olivera cumple hoy 112 años|website=Elperiodicoextremadura.com|accessdate=15 December 2017}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Longevity}} [[Category:Spanish supercentenarians| ]] [[Category:Lists of supercentenarians by country|Spanish]] [[Category:Lists of Spanish people|Supercentenarians]]

revision.comment: Importing Wikidata [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "Wikimedia list article" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|Wikimedia list article}} {{list incomplete|date=April 2018}} The following list contains places which uses a [[number]] as its name.
==1== * [[Een]], The Netherlands (= one)
==2== * [[Zweibrücken]], Germany, ''zwei'' means ''two'' in German and ''Brücken'' means ''bridges'' * [[Duas Bocas Biological Reserve]] ("2 mouths"), Brazil * [[Duas Barras]] ("2 bars"), Rio de Janeiro, Brazil * [[Duas Estradas]] ("2 roads"), Paraíba, Brazil * [[Duas Igrejas (Paredes)|Duas Igrejas]] ("2 churches"), Paredes, Portugal * [[Dos Pilas]] ("2 wells"), Guatemala * [[Dos Vientos]] and [[Dos Vientos Open Space]] ("2 winds"), California
==3== * [[Dreikirchen]], Germany (= three churches) * [[Trois-Ponts]] (German: Dreibrücken), Belgium (= three bridges) * [[Trois-Rivières]], Canada (= three rivers) * [[Trois-Rivières, Guadeloupe]] * [[Driehuis]], The Netherlands (= three houses) * [[Tres Cantos]] ("3 corners"), Madrid, Spain * [[Tres Cerros]] ("3 hills"), Argentina * [[Três Coroas]] ("3 crowns"), Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil * [[Tres Cruces]] ("3 crosses"), Uruguay * [[Tres de Febrero Partido]] ("February 3rd"), Argentina * [[Tres Valles]] ("3 valleys"), Mexico
==4== * [[Big Four, West Virginia]] * [[Nunspeet|Vierhouten]], The Netherlands (= four pieces of wood) * [[Cuatro Caminos]] ("4 roads"), one of the first metro stations in Madrid * [[Cuatro Cañadas]] ("4 paths"), Bolivia * [[Cuatro Ciénegas]] ("4 marshes"), Mexico * [[Cuatro Torres]] ("4 towers"), Madrid business district * [[Cuatro Vientos]] ("4 winds"), Madrid neighbourhood and military-civil airport and museum
==5== * [[Vijfhuizen]], The Netherlands (= five houses) * [[Cinco Ranch]], Texas * [[Five Forks, Calhoun County, West Virginia]] * [[Five Forks, Ritchie County, West Virginia]] * [[Five Forks, Upshur County, West Virginia]]
==6== * [[Six, West Virginia]] * [[Sixes, Georgia]] * [[Sixes, Oregon]] – The community was named after the Sixes river. Accounts vary as to how the river got its name. One local postmaster said Sixes was named for a [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] chief. * [[6th_of_October_(city)|El Sādis Min Uktōber]] or '''The 6th of October''', [[Egypt]].
==7== * [[Siebenhirten]], Austria is one of 89 municipalities within [[Vienna]] and also the name of an underground railway station. * [[Zevenhuizen (disambiguation)|Zevenhuizen]], several places in the Netherlands (= seven houses) * [[Sete Cidades (disambiguation)|Sete Cidades]]<!--Intentional link to DAB page--> ("7 cities"), Azores (Portugal) and Piauí (Brazil) * [[Sete Fontes]] ("7 springs"), Braga, Portugal * [[Sete Lagoas]] ("7 lagoons"), Minas Gerais, Brazil
==8== * [[Acht (Eifel)]], Germany * [[Eight, West Virginia]] * [[Achtmaal]], The Netherlands (= eight houses) * [[Ocho Ríos]] ("8 rivers"), Jamaica
==9== * [[Neunkirchen, Austria]] * [[Nueve de Julio (disambiguation)|Nueve de Julio]] ("July 9th"), several towns in Argentina * [[Nueve de Julio Department (disambiguation)|Nueve de Julio Department]] ("July 9th"), several [[Departments of Argentina|departments]] in Argentina * [[Nueve de Julio District]] ("July 9th"), Peru * [[Nueve de Julio Partido]] ("July 9th"), Argentina
==10== * [[Tiengeboden]], The Netherlands (= Ten Commandments) * [[Diez de Octubre]] ("October 10th"), Cuba
==11== * [[Once de Octubre]] ("October 11th"), Argentina * [[Once de Septiembre]] ("September 11th"), Argentina
==12== * https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naturschutzgebiet_Linowsee-Dutzendsee#Dutzendsee Dutzendsee, Germany, earlier a slightly different written name, later folk-etymologically changed, ''Dutzend'' / ''See'' means ''a dozen'' / ''lake'' in German * https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dutzendteich Dutzendteich, Großer and Kleiner, ''Dutzend'' / ''Teich'' means ''a dozen'' / ''pond'' in German, two ponds, a big and a small one, in Germany * https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dutzendteich_(Nürnberg) Dutzendteich, one of 87 statistical districts (Statischer Bezirk) of [[Nürnberg]], Germany * [[Zwölfaxing]], Austria. ''Zwölf'' means ''twelve'' in German, hence its a city with a number in its name. * [[Doce de Octubre]] ("October 12th"), Argentina
==13== * [[Trece Mártires]] ("13 martyrs"), Philippines
==14== * Vierzehn is an incorporated village of [[Rainbach im Mühlkreis]], Austria * [[Catorce, San Luis Potosí]], Mexico ** [[Real de Catorce]] ("[[spanish colonial real|real]] [a kind of [[currency of Spanish America]]] of [value] 14", or from "14 killed soldiers"), Mexico * [[Catorce de Noviembre]] ("November 14th"), Panama (see more at [[Catorce]])
==18== * [[18-Hazari]], [[18-Hazari Tehsil]], Jhang District, Punjab, Pakistan * [[Dieciocho Airport]], Costa Rica * [[Dieciocho de Julio]] ("July 18th"), Uruguay * [[Dieciocho de Mayo]] ("May 18th"), Uruguay
==20== * [[Twenty, Lincolnshire]] * [[Veinte de Junio]] ("June 20th"), BBAA, Argentina * [[Veinte Reales]], Philippines ("20 [[spanish colonial real|real]]es [a coin]", the price for the lands or for the use of a magical spring)
==24== * [[North 24 Parganas district]] * [[South 24 Parganas]] * [[Veinticuatro de Mayo]] and [[Veinticuatro de Mayo Canton]] ("May 24th"), Ecuador
==25== * [[Veinticinco de Agosto]] ("August 25th"), Uruguay * [[Veinticinco de Diciembre]] ("December 25th"), Paraguay * [[Veinticinco de Mayo (disambiguation)|Veinticinco de Mayo]] ("May 25th") (several places in Argentina and Uruguay)
==26== * [[Twentysix, Kentucky]] - Twentysix is an unincorporated community in Morgan County, Kentucky. The story is that the community's first postmaster, Martha Rowland, submitted 25 possible community names, and then jotted down "26," which was the year she submitted the list, 1926.
==27== * [[Veintisiete de Abril]] ("April 27th"), Costa Rica
==28== * [[Veintiocho de Noviembre]] ("November 28th"), Argentina
==29== * [[Twentynine Palms, California]]
== 33 == * [[Treinta y Tres]] and [[Treinta y Tres Department]], Uruguay ("from the [[Treinta y Tres Orientales|33 original fighters for the independence]]")
==40== * [[Cuarenta Casas]] ("40 houses") archaeological site, Mexico
==56== * [[Fifty-Six, Arkansas]] – When founding the community in 1918, locals submitted the name "Newcomb" for the settlement. This request was rejected, and the federal government internally named the community for its school district number (56).<ref>Earngey, Bill. "Arkansas Roadsides." 1978 East Mountain Press. [[Eureka Springs, Arkansas]]. pp. 32. {{ISBN|0-9619592-0-7}}.</ref> It has frequently been noted on lists of [[Place names considered unusual|unusual place names]].<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0Ia7Rga26OkC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA7#v=onepage&q&f=false | title=You Live Where?: Interesting and Unusual Facts about where We Live | publisher=iUniverse | author=Thompson, George E. | year=2009 | pages=7}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arkansas.com/things-to-do/history-heritage/colorful-names/ |title=Colorful Names |publisher=Arkansas Department of Parks & Tourism |accessdate=14 July 2014 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131124055328/http://www.arkansas.com/things-to-do/history-heritage/colorful-names/ |archivedate=November 24, 2013 }}</ref>
==60== * [[Hatvan]] – A town in Hungary located 60 km from the capital city.
==66== * [[Sixty Six, South Carolina]]
==76== * [[Seventy Six, Kentucky]] * [[Seventy-Six, Missouri]]
==84== * [[Eighty Four, Pennsylvania]] – Eighty Four was originally named Smithville. Due to postal confusion with another town of the same name, its name was changed to "Eighty Four" on July 28, 1884.<ref name=Ledger>{{Cite news |title=Eighty-four, Pa. turns 100 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=3tYSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fvsDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2518,3962457 |date=1984-07-28 |newspaper=[[The Ledger]] |agency=[[The Associated Press]] |accessdate=2009-10-02}}</ref>
==88== * [[Eighty Eight, Kentucky]] – As reported in a [[New York Times]] article, the town was named in 1860 by Dabnie Nunnally, the community's first postmaster. He had little faith in the legibility of his handwriting, and thought that using numbers would solve the problem. He then reached into his pocket and came up with 88 cents.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=940DE5D9113DF936A3575BC0A96E948260|work=New York Times|title=Eighty Eight Journal; A Date That Will Live in Kentucky |first=Lonnie|last=Wheeler|date=1988-08-05|accessdate=2007-11-22}}</ref> Another explanation is that the hamlet is 8.8 miles from Glasgow.<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3Lac2FUSj_oC&lpg=PA49&dq=cannon%20ky&pg=PA90#v=onepage&q=cannon%20ky&f=false | title=Kentucky Place Names | publisher=University Press of Kentucky | year=1987 | accessdate=2013-04-28 | author=Rennick, Robert M. | pages=90}}</ref>
==96== * [[Ninety Six, South Carolina]] – There is much confusion about the mysterious name, "Ninety-Six," and the true origin may never be known. Speculation has led to the mistaken belief that it was 96 miles to the nearest Cherokee settlement of Keowee; to a counting of creeks crossing the main road leading from Lexington, SC, to Ninety-Six; to an interpretation of a Welsh expression, "nant-sych," meaning "dry gulch." Pitcher [[Bill Voiselle]] of the Boston Braves was from Ninety Six, South Carolina, and wore uniform number 96.
==100== * [[Hundred, West Virginia]] – It was named for [[Henry Church]] and his wife, the first settlers who lived to be 109 and 106. Hundred is the only place in the [[United States]] with this name.
==101== * [[Wonowon, British Columbia]] ("one-oh-one") – located at Mile 101 on [[British Columbia Highway 97|Highway 97]], the [[Alaska Highway]].
==400== * [[Fjärdhundra]], Sweden
==1000==
* [[Thousand Islands]] – an archipelago in the St. Lawrence River along the boundary between New York and Ontario * [[Thousand Oaks, California]] * [[Thousandsticks, Kentucky]]
==1770== * [[Seventeen Seventy, Queensland]] – Although the town is referred to locally as "1770", the official name of the town is "Seventeen Seventy". It commemorates the arrival of Captain James Cook on the ''Endeavour'' in that year.
==20,000== * [[Ventimiglia]], Italy (coincidental, as it comes from ''Album Intimilium'')
==40,010== * [[Shimanto, Kōchi (city)|Shimanto, Kōchi]], Japan
== Names with trailing numbers == * Petersdorf I, Styria, Austria * Petersdorf II, until end of 2014, Styria, Austria, see https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petersdorf_II
* Takern I, part of the community St. Margarethen an der Raab, Styria, Austria, see https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/St._Margarethen_an_der_Raab * Takern II, part of the same community, Styria, Austria
* Krems I, a part of the village [[Leezen]], Germany * Krems II, a part of a different region, but again in [[Schleswig-Holstein]], Germany
* [[Canal de Isabel II]], water provider company, for its initial conducting channel works
==References== <references/>
{{Place name etymologies}} [[Category:Lists of place names|Numeric names]] [[Category:Numbers|Places]]

China (Takla Makan) *[[Zeravshan River|Zeravshan]] - [[Tajikistan]], [[Uzbekistan]] *[[Zijiang River|Zijiang]] (Zi)- China

revision.comment: Added {{[[:Template:one source|one source]]}} tag to article ([[WP:TW|TW]])
Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
The [[Bailiwick of Guernsey]] has had a number of [[windmill]]s over the centuries. They were mostly corn mills, and about half of those built survive in one form or another.
==Guernsey== * '''Cote des Vardes''' Located in Montville Road, [[St Peter Port]], used to grind stone,<ref name=SGI/> has been converted into a three-storey property.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cooperbrouard.com/uploads/attachments/property_2478514.pdf |title=Cote des Vardes}}</ref>
* '''Delancey Windmill''' This mill was standing in 1847.<ref name=HP050347/>
* '''L'Hyvreuse Windmill''' The site of the ''L'Hyvreuse Windmill'' is now occupied by the Victoria Tower, built in 1848.<ref name=Tower>{{cite web | url = http://www.islandlife.org/victoria.htm| publisher = Islandlife.org| title = Victoria Tower| accessdate = 2008-05-02}}</ref>
* '''Le Hechet Windmill''' Photographed in the 19th century, ''Le Hechet'' was located in St Saviour, presumably off Rue du Hechet.<ref>{{cite book |last=Strappini |first=Richard |title=St Martin, Guernsey, Channel Islands, a parish history from 1204 |date=2004 |page=71}}</ref>
* '''Le Moulin des Monts'''
''Le Moulin des Monts'', [[St Sampson's]], was destroyed by [[lightning]] in 1660. Its site is now occupied by the De Saumarez Memorial in Delancey Park.<ref name=Monts>{{cite web|url=http://www.gov.gg/ccm/general/parishes/st-sampson/de-saumarez-memorial.en |publisher=States of Guernsey |title=De Saumarez Memorial |accessdate=2008-05-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060505220809/http://www.gov.gg/ccm/general/parishes/st-sampson/de-saumarez-memorial.en |archivedate=May 5, 2006 }}</ref>
* '''Moulin Mont Saint, [[Saint Saviour, Guernsey|St Saviour]]'''
A windmill to grind stone was established in St Saviour in 1833.<ref name="SGI">{{cite book |publisher=J.E. Collins |title=The Strangers' Guide to the Islands of Guernsey and Jersey |date=1833}}</ref>{{rp|98}} It is currently{{when|date=August 2018}} under restoration.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/local/guernsey/hi/people_and_places/history/newsid_8609000/8609746.stm |publisher=BBC Guernsey |title=Restoring a Guernsey windmill at Perelle |accessdate=2017-08-30}}</ref>
* '''Moulin Huet, [[St Martin, Guernsey|St Martin]]'''
''Moulin Huet'' is a [[tower mill]]. Possibly named after Walter Huet, [[List of Governors of Guernsey|Governor of Guernsey in 1372]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Strappini |first=Richard |title=St Martin, Guernsey, Channel Islands, a parish history from 1204 |date=2004 |page=3}}</ref> It was derelict and capless by 1949 when photographed by Donald Muggeridge.<ref name=Mug>{{cite web|url=http://library.kent.ac.uk/library/special/html/mills/flint.htm |publisher=UNIVERSITY OF KENT AT CANTERBURY |title=The Donald W. Muggeridge Collection of Mill Photographs - GUERNSEY |accessdate=2008-05-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070811225855/http://library.kent.ac.uk/library/special/html/mills/flint.htm |archivedate=August 11, 2007 }}</ref> The mill had lost its sails by 1926, even though the cap and sail cross remained. The tower is located at the top of ''Old Mill Road'' and ''Les Camps du Moulin'', St Martin.<ref>{{cite book |last=Strappini |first=Richard |title=St Martin, Guernsey, Channel Islands, a parish history from 1204 |date=2004 |page=28}}</ref>
* '''Ozannes Windmill'''
Ozannes Mill, in ''Ruette Braye'' was in existence in 1897.<ref>{{cite book |last=Strappini |first=Richard |title=St Martin, Guernsey, Channel Islands, a parish history from 1204 |date=2004 |page=71}}</ref>
* '''Petit Bot Windmill'''
The windmill, located at the top of Petit Bot Valley was photographed in good condition before it was totally destroyed. Its exact location has not been found. It could be at the top of the St Martin or Forest valleys.<ref>{{cite book |last=Strappini |first=Richard |title=St Martin, Guernsey, Channel Islands, a parish history from 1204 |date=2004 |page=71}}</ref>
* '''Sausmarez Windmill, St. Martin''' The converted mill still stands in Steam Mill Lane, it houses a jewellery business which also operates a store from the converted St. Peter's mill in [[Jersey]].<ref name=World>{{cite web | url = http://www.windmillworld.com/uk/guernsey.htm| publisher = Windmill World| title = Windmills of Guernsey| accessdate = 2008-05-02}}</ref>
* '''Vale Windmill'''
A windmill was standing on this site in 1847.<ref name=HP050347>{{Cite news |title=Shipping Intelligence |newspaper=The Hull Packet and East Riding Times |location=Hull |date=5 March 1847 |issue=3241 }}</ref> Vale Windmill is a five-storey tower mill that was built in 1850.<ref name=Vale/> Photographs show it to have had four patent sails mounted in a canister, and an ogee cap similar in shape to those found in Suffolk, winded by a fantail. The mill had a stage at first floor level.<ref name=Vale2>{{cite web | url = http://www.cipostcard.co.nz/guernsey/gsyll204w.jpg| publisher = cipostcards.co.nz| title = Guernsey - The Vale Mill - Le Moulin du Valle| accessdate = 2008-05-02}}</ref> It was converted into an artillery observation post by the [[German occupation of the Channel Islands|Germans during the Second World War]]. This work entailed a three-storey extension being built on the mill tower, making it {{convert|21|m|ftin}} high overall.<ref name=Vale>{{cite web | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/guernsey/content/articles/2006/07/31/vale_mill_update_july_2006_feature.shtml| publisher = BBC| title = The Vale Mill| accessdate = 2008-05-02}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> The windmill featured on a [https://web.archive.org/web/20130715113504/http://web.jet.es/plopezp/filatelia/fila_uk2.htm 2p postage due] stamp issued by the Guernsey post office in 1982.
== Alderney ==
There is a record of a windmill owned by the King before 1242 on The Blaye.
Alderney had a windmill built in 1560.
==Sark== * '''Sark Windmill'''
''Sark Windmill'' was built in 1571 at the [[seigneur]]'s expense. It is situated on the highest point on [[Sark]] (114 metres or 374 feet above sea level), called ''Le Moulin'' after the windmill. It is a three-storey tower mill with an [[ogee]] cap. In the early 19th century the mill was burned by Sark tenants protesting against the seigneurial system there, but it was later refitted with new machinery and heightened.<ref name="Watts2006">{{cite book|author=Martin Watts|title=Windmills|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PJ7-M8lFo_UC&pg=PA13|accessdate=13 April 2013|year=2006|publisher=Osprey Publishing|isbn=978-0-7478-0653-0|pages=13–}}</ref><ref name=Sarkhist>{{cite web|url=http://www.sark.info/static/government/old_website/static/history.htm |publisher=sarkinfo |title=SHORT HISTORY OF SARK |accessdate=2008-05-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071015075847/http://www.sark.info/static/government/old_website/static/history.htm |archivedate=October 15, 2007 }}</ref> It was working by wind until 1917<ref name=Sark>{{cite web | url = http://www.islandlife.org/attractions_sark.htm| publisher = Islandlife| title = Sark Attractions| accessdate = 2008-05-02 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080415134041/http://www.islandlife.org/attractions_sark.htm |archivedate = 2008-04-15}}</ref> although the sails were removed during [[World War I]]. It was used as an observation tower during the German occupation. The mill had four double patent sails, and was winded by a fantail.<ref name=Card>Postcard 4548; The Mill, Sark; Judges Ltd., Hastings.</ref> The mill featured on the 1971 and 1977 2p coins issued by Guernsey.<ref name="Cuhaj2011">{{cite book|author=George S. Cuhaj|title=Collecting World Coins: Circulating Issues 1901 - Present|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TMclvj4t94EC&pg=PA436|accessdate=13 April 2013|date=28 February 2011|publisher=Krause Publications|isbn=978-1-4402-1884-2|pages=436–}}</ref>
* '''Little Sark Windmill'''
''Little Sark Windmill'' was a tower mill. The tower remains today, mostly covered in ivy.<ref name=Card2>Postcard titled "The Old Mill - Harvest Time - Little Sark", photograph by Bryan J Dolan</ref>
<gallery> Image:Sark windmill working.jpg |Sark windmill c1905 Image:Windmill - Sark.jpg|Sark windmill, 2007 Image:The Old Windmill, Little Sark - geograph.org.uk - 65.jpg|Little Sark windmill, 1964 </gallery>
==References== {{reflist|2}}

page.title: National Council for the Social Studies

revision.comment: /* Social Studies */
revision.text:
The '''National Council for the Social Studies''' ('''NCSS''') is a U.S.-based association devoted to supporting [[social studies]] education. It is affiliated with various regional or state level social studies associations, including: the [[Middle States Council for the Social Studies]], the Washington State Council for the Social Studies, the New York City UFT Association for the Teaching of Social Studies, the Michigan Council for the Social Studies,<ref>[http://www.socialstudies.org/ local NCSS Affiliated Councils]</ref> Massachusetts Council for the Social Studies.,<ref>http://www.masscouncil.org/?page_id=579</ref> and [[Virginia Council for the Social Studies]]. They publish several journals; their flagship publication<ref>[https://www.bu.edu/sed/martells-article-featured-by-national-council-for-the-social-studies/ ''Martell’s Article Featured by National Council for the Social Studies.''] Boston University. School of Education. 18 September 2013. Accessed 9 August 2017.</ref> being a [[Peer review|peer-reviewed]]<ref>[http://libguides.library.drexel.edu/k12-literacy-socialstudies ''Teaching Content Areas - Literacy and Social Studies: Home.''] Drexel University. 2017. Accessed 9 August 2017.</ref> journal titled [[Social Education]] which, according to their website, aims to strike "a balance of theoretical content and practical teaching ideas."<ref>[https://www.socialstudies.org/publications/socialeducation ''Social Education.''] National Council for the Social Studies. 2017. Accessed 9 August 2017.</ref>
==History== Founded in 1921, NCSS engages and supports educators in strengthening and advocating social studies. With members in all the 50 states, the [[District of Columbia]], and 69 foreign countries, NCSS serves as an umbrella organization for elementary, secondary, and college teachers of history, geography, economics, political science, sociology, psychology, anthropology, and law-related education. Organized into a network of more than 110 affiliated state, local, and regional councils and associated groups, the NCSS membership represents K–12 classroom teachers, college and university faculty members, curriculum designers and specialists, social studies supervisors, and leaders in the various disciplines that constitute the social studies.
==Social Studies== NCSS defines social studies as "the integrated study of the social sciences and humanities to promote civic competence." Within the school program, social studies provides coordinated, systematic study drawing upon such disciplines as anthropology, archaeology, economics, geography, history, law, philosophy, political science, psychology, religion, and sociology, as well as appropriate content from the humanities, mathematics, and natural sciences. In essence, social studies promotes knowledge of and involvement in civic affairs. And because civic issues—such as health care, crime, and foreign policy—are multidisciplinary in nature, understanding these issues and developing resolutions to them requires multidisciplinary education. These characteristics are the key defining aspects of social studies.
==Expectations of Excellence== In 2010, the council published National Curriculum Standards for Social Studies: A Framework for Teaching, Learning and Assessment. This publication is an update and revision of Expectations of Excellence: Curriculum Standards for Social Studies originally published in 1994. The National Curriculum Standards provides an articulated K–12 social studies program that serves as a framework for the integration of other national standards in social studies, including U.S. and world history, civics and government, geography, global education, and economics. NCSS standards ensure that an integrated social science, behavioral science, and humanities approach for achieving academic and civic competence is available to guide social studies decision makers in K–12 schools.
The NCSS framework consists of ten themes incorporating fields of study that correspond with one or more relevant disciplines. The organization believes that effective social studies programs include experiences that provide for the study of: Culture; Time, Continuity, and Change; People, Places, and Environments; Individual Development and Identity; Individuals, Groups, and Institutions; Power, Authority, and Governance; Production, Distribution, and Consumption; Science, Technology, and Society; Global Connections; and Civic Ideals and Practices.
==Awards== The NCSS gives a number of awards<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.socialstudies.org/awards |website=www.socialstudies.org |title=Awards and Grants|publisher=National Council for the Social Studies |accessdate=17 October 2015 }}</ref> including: * ''Outstanding Social Studies Teacher of the Year Awards'' - "recognize exceptional classroom social studies teachers for grades K-6, 5-8, and 7-12 who teach social studies regularly and systematically in elementary school settings, and at least half-time in middle or junior high and high school settings."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.socialstudies.org/awards/teacherofyear |website=www.socialstudies.org |title=NCSS Outstanding Social Studies Teacher of the Year|publisher=National Council for the Social Studies |accessdate=17 October 2015 }}</ref> * ''Award for Global Understanding Given in Honor of James M. Becker'' - "recognizes a social studies educator (or a team of educators) who has made notable contributions in helping social studies students increase their understanding of the world."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.socialstudies.org/award_for_global_understanding_given_in_honor_of_james_m_becker |website=www.socialstudies.org |title=Award for Global Understanding given in honor of James M. Becker |publisher=National Council for the Social Studies |accessdate=17 October 2015 }}</ref> * ''FASSE Christa McAuliffe Reach for the Stars Award'' - "to help a social studies educator make his or her dream of innovative social studies a reality. Grants will be given to assist classroom teachers in: 1) developing and implementing imaginative, innovative, and illustrative social studies teaching strategies; and 2) supporting student implementation of innovative social studies, citizenship projects, field experiences, and community connections."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.socialstudies.org/awards/fasse/fasse-mcauliffe |website=www.socialstudies.org |title=Christa McAuliffe Reach for the Stars Award |publisher=National Council for the Social Studies |accessdate=17 October 2015 }}</ref> * ''NCSS Research Awards'' - "NCSS and the Research Committee sponsor three annual research awards designed to recognize substantive scholarly inquiry in social studies education."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.socialstudies.org/awards/research/ |website=www.socialstudies.org |title=NCSS Research Awards |publisher=National Council for the Social Studies |accessdate=17 October 2015 }}</ref> * ''Carter G. Woodson Book Awards'' - "presented to exemplary books written for children and young people each year at the NCSS Annual Conference."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.socialstudies.org/awards/woodson |website=www.socialstudies.org |title=Carter G. Woodson Book Awards |publisher=National Council for the Social Studies |accessdate=17 October 2015 }}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Children and Young Adult Literature}} * [[New England History Teachers' Association]]
==References== <references />
==External links== * [http://www.socialstudies.org/ NCSS] * [http://www.socialstudies.org/conference Social studies conference]

revision.comment: Edited link to Alaska Elevation site. (kw)
revision.text:
Currently, the best source for nationwide LiDAR availability from public sources is the United States Interagency Elevation Inventory (USIEI).[http://www.csc.noaa.gov/inventory/] The USIEI is a collaborative effort of NOAA and the U.S. Geological Survey, with contributions from the [[Federal Emergency Management Agency]]. The inventory displays high-accuracy topographic and bathymetric data for the US, and it's intended to be a comprehensive, nationwide listing of known high-accuracy topographic data, including [[lidar]]. The most recent inventory was completed August 2013 and will be updated annually. Note, however, that getting access to the data is often less than straightforward in the current implementation. History: In the United States, the [[United States Geological Survey]] (USGS) was the lead agency coordinating efforts across multiple agencies towards a [[National LIDAR Dataset]]. The first meeting, a National LIDAR Initiative Strategy Meeting, was held at USGS headquarters in Reston, Virginia in February 2007. In May 2008 a second meeting[http://www.asprs.org/publications/pers/2008journal/september/highlight.pdf] was held, co-sponsored by USGS, [[NASA]], and the [[AASG]]. In 2009, several sessions at the annual [[American Society for Photogrammetry and Remote Sensing]] meeting were devoted to this initiative.[http://lidar.cr.usgs.gov/asprs_2009.php] The USGS website remains a central source for information about the national initiative, and it includes presentation materials from the various meetings about the subject. This site also discusses how the USGS incorporates [[LIDAR]] data into the [[National Elevation Dataset]]. In addition to USGS and NASA, numerous government agencies have indicated their interest in such a project, including [[National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency]] (NGA), the [[Federal Emergency Management Agency]] (FEMA), [[US Army Corps of Engineers]], [[NOAA]], and [[Natural Resources Conservation Service|NRCS]].[http://www.asprs.org/publications/pers/2008journal/september/highlight.pdf] While there is consensus at a federal level supporting the creation of a National LIDAR Dataset, key aspects remain unresolved, including funding, data specifications, and the delineation of agency roles and responsibilities.[http://www.asprs.org/publications/pers/2008journal/september/highlight.pdf] While these issues are pending, the following states are among those moving forward with their own statewide LIDAR datasets: {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! State ! Dataset Status ! Source |- | Alaska | Partial | [https://elevation.alaska.gov Alaska Elevation Inventory & Distribution] |- | Connecticut | Complete (med-res) | [http://clear.uconn.edu/data/CT_DEM/ct_dem_download.asp CT Lidar 10' DEM]; see also this [http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/sanborn-completes-connecticut-statewide-data-collection-300284077.html news] |- | Delaware | Complete | [http://stateplanning.delaware.gov/information/gis_data.shtml Delaware Spatial Data Framework] |- | Florida | Partial | [http://www.floridadisaster.org/gis/LiDAR/ FL Coastline Project] |- | Idaho | Partial | [http://www.idaholidar.org/data ID LiDAR Consortium] |- | Illinois | Partial | [http://clearinghouse.isgs.illinois.edu/data/elevation/illinois-height-modernization-ilhmp-lidar-data Illinois Height Modernization (ILHMP): LiDAR Data] |- | Indiana | Completed | [http://gis.iu.edu/datasetInfo/statewide/in_2011.php Indiana Spatial Data Portal] |- | Iowa | Complete | [http://www.geotree.uni.edu/lidarProject.aspx IA GeoTree Lidar Mapping Project] |- | Kansas | Partial | [http://www.kansasgis.org/resources/lidar.cfm Kansas GIS/DASC] |- | Kentucky | Partial | [http://www.lojic.org/main/metadata/index.html Metadata], [http://lojic.maps.arcgis.com/apps/webappviewer/index.html?id=ca6a2733016a4bbc89b35628babf9072 Grid] and [ftp://ftp.kymartian.ky.gov/kyaped/DEMs_5FT/ 5ft DEMs] |- | Louisiana | ~Complete | [http://atlas.lsu.edu/ Louisiana Atlas] |- | [[Maryland lidar availability|Maryland]] | Partial | [http://imap.maryland.gov/Pages/lidar.aspx MD iMap], [http://dnrweb.dnr.state.md.us/gis/data/lidar/ MD DNR LiDAR], or [http://www.csc.noaa.gov/digitalcoast/data/coastallidar/download.html NOAA] |- | Massachusetts | Partial - Boston area only | Available for purchase from MassGIS [http://www.mass.gov/mgis/massgis.htm] |- | Minnesota | Complete | [http://www.mngeo.state.mn.us/chouse/elevation/lidar.html MN Lidar Status] |- | New Hampshire | Partial | [http://www.granit.unh.edu/data/orderdata/prepackagedproducts.html GRANIT/Coastal data] |- | New Jersey | Partial | [https://njgin.state.nj.us/oit/gis/NJ_NJGINExplorer/docs/NJ_lidar_status.pdf NJ Lidar Status] |- | New York | Partial | [http://gis.ny.gov/elevation/lidar-coverage.htm NYS Lidar Coverage], or [http://www.orthos.dhses.ny.gov/ NYS Orthos] |- | North Carolina | Complete | [http://www.ncfloodmaps.com/ NC Floodmapping Program]
[http://www.nconemap.com/ NCDOT Elevation Data] |- | North Dakota | Partial | [http://lidar.swc.nd.gov/ ND LIDAR Dissemination Mapservice] |- | Ohio | Complete | [http://ogrip.oit.ohio.gov/ProjectsInitiatives/StatewideImagery.aspx Ohio Statewide Imagery Program] |- | Oregon | Partial | [http://www.oregongeology.org/sub/projects/olc/default.htm Oregon Lidar Consortium] |- | Pennsylvania | Complete | [http://www.dcnr.state.pa.us/topogeo/pamap/lidar/index.htm PAMAP Program LiDAR] |- | South Carolina | Partial | [http://www.dnr.sc.gov/GIS/lidar.html SC Lidar Consortium] |- | Tennessee | Partial | [http://tnmap.tn.gov/TNMapResources.asp TN GIS Portal] |- | Texas | Partial | [https://tnris.org/data-catalog/ TNRIS/Texas] |- | Utah | Partial | [http://gis.utah.gov/data/elevation-terrain-data/ UT Lidar datasets] |- | Vermont | Partial | [http://vcgi.vermont.gov/lidar VCGI] |- | Virginia | Partial | [http://www.virginialidar.com Virginia Lidar] Site is Closed |- | West Virginia | Partial | [http://www.wvgis.wvu.edu/lidar/ WV GIS Technical Center] |- | Wisconsin | In progress | [http://news.sco.wisc.edu/news/state-land-information/wisconsin-department-of-commerce-lidar-grants-announced.html WI: 14 counties] |- | Wyoming | In progress |[http://www.wy.nrcs.usda.gov/wygis/lidar.html Wyoming Statewide LIDAR Effort] |} Regardless of the degree of state coordination, some counties choose to handle (and control) high resolution LiDAR acquisition and distribution on their own. Such counties include: {| class="wikitable plainlinks neverexpand" |- ! State ! County |- | Arkansas | [http://www.co.benton.ar.us/GIS/Projects.aspx Benton] · [http://geodata.co.washington.ar.us/website/washington_county/viewer.htm Washington] |- | California | [http://egis3.lacounty.gov/dataportal/index.php/2010/02/19/2006-5-foot-1-7m-digital-elevation-model-dem/ Los Angeles] · [http://online.sfsu.edu/ehines/arra_golden_gate_lidar_project.htm Marin] · [http://coast.noaa.gov/dataviewer/index.html?action=advsearch&qType=in&qFld=ID&qVal=4793# Orange] · [http://coast.noaa.gov/dataviewer/index.html?action=advsearch&qType=in&qFld=ID&qVal=4703 Sonoma] |- | Florida | [http://csc-s-maps-q.csc.noaa.gov/dataviewer/viewer.html Brevard] · [http://gis.broward.org/LIDAR.htm Broward] · [http://csc-s-maps-q.csc.noaa.gov/dataviewer/viewer.html Clay] · [http://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/nmmrview/metadata.jsp?id=gov.noaa.csc.maps:fl2006_escambia&view=html Escambia] · [http://csc-s-maps-q.csc.noaa.gov/dataviewer/viewer.html Gulf] · [http://csc-s-maps-q.csc.noaa.gov/dataviewer/viewer.html Holmes] · [http://csc-s-maps-q.csc.noaa.gov/dataviewer/viewer.html Indian River] · [http://csc-s-maps-q.csc.noaa.gov/dataviewer/viewer.html Jefferson] · [http://leegis.leegov.com/GISData.htm Lee] · [http://csc-s-maps-q.csc.noaa.gov/dataviewer/viewer.html Leon] · [http://csc-s-maps-q.csc.noaa.gov/dataviewer/viewer.html Okaloosa] · [http://csc-s-maps-q.csc.noaa.gov/dataviewer/viewer.html Putnam] · [http://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/nmmrview/metadata.jsp?id=gov.noaa.csc.maps:fl2004_stjohns&view=html St. Johns] · [http://coast.noaa.gov/dataviewer/index.html?action=advsearch&qType=in&qFld=ID&qVal=2619 Baldwin] · [http://coast.noaa.gov/dataviewer/index.html?action=advsearch&qType=in&qFld=ID&qVal=2617 Barrow] · page.title: Nomenclature of States in North East India

revision.comment: en-IN
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=July 2018}} {{Multiple issues|section=| {{duplication|date=November 2015}} {{Synthesis|date=November 2015}} }} {{merge|List of Indian state and union territory name etymologies|reason=Tagged as duplicate since 2015. No apparent reason why a particular region needs a different list |date=August 2017}} '''North East India''' is the north easternmost part of [[India]]. It comprises seven states; namely [[Assam]], [[Tripura]], [[Manipur]], [[Arunachal Pradesh]], [[Meghalaya]], [[Mizoram]] and [[Nagaland]]. The states of Assam ([[Kamarupa]] & [[Davaka]]), Tripura, and Manipur are ancient in existence, while rest curbed out from Assam in late twentieth century, i.e., Nagaland in 1963, Meghalaya in 1972, Arunachal Pradesh in 1975 and the state of Mizoram come into existence as late as 1987.
==Etymologies of state names== It is common in names of North Eastern Indian states like rest of country of usage of [[Sanskrit]] word referring to quality or feature of land.
===Assam=== The name of Assam state derived from the Sanskrit word 'Asama', which means unequal or uneven referring to its geology which is equal mix of river valleys and hills.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indiatravelogue.com/dest/nest/nest.html |title=Assam Etymology |publisher=indiatravelogue.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-24}}</ref>
===Manipur=== Manipur state known by said Sanskrit word which means land of jewels. It seems that naming the said name in account of the past prosperity of land.<ref>{{Citation| surname= Mee, Foley | given= Erin B.,Helene P. | title= Antigone on the Contemporary World Stage|publisher=Oxford University Press| year= 2011|pages=111}}</ref>
===Tripura=== Tripura by which said state is known is another Sanskrit word which means "lands of three cities".{{cn|date=March 2018}}
===Arunachal Pradesh=== Arunachal Pradesh is a Sanskrit word which means land of rising sun as state is located in the easternmost part of the country and gets first sunrise in the country.<ref>G. K. Ghosh, Shukla Ghosh (1995), ''Indian Textiles: Past and Present'', p.229 Arunachal Pradesh may be termed as the land of rising sun since it in this part of the country that Sun ray first kisses Indian soil. In other words Sun rises first in Arunachal Pradesh before rest of our country.</ref>
===Meghalaya=== The state of Meghalaya has reputation of having highest rainfall as compared to other states of country. The wettest place in the world Mawsynram, is located in Meghalaya. Said feature of land is reflected in its name in Sanskrit which means Abode of clouds.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nenanews.com/meghalya.htm |title=Meghalaya Etymology |publisher=nenanews.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-24}}</ref>
===Mizoram=== The states of Nagaland and Mizoram are exceptions where Sanskrit words are not used in the state name. Mizoram was named after the Mizo tribal dialect and refers to their land.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.nlup.mizoram.gov.in/?phek=bawm&bid=25|title=Mizoram Etymology |publisher=en.nlup.mizoram.gov.in|date= |accessdate=2011-11-24}}</ref>
===Nagaland=== Tha name Nagaland consists of two words: the 'Naga', a native term for umbrella of tribes and [[English language|English]] word 'land', collectively meaning land of Naga tribes. Until recent times term 'Naga' was foreign to Naga tribes themselves, there was no generic term for entire group of tribes, who rather identify themselves as Konyak, Tangkhul, Angami, Sema, Lotha, Ao, Pangmei, Zeliangrong, Mao and Khiumniungan etc.
The word 'Naga' is attributed to two origins. One theory states that in [[Myanmar]], Naga tribes are called Na-Ka, which in [[Burmese language]] means 'people with pierced ear lobes'. The British explorers which comes into contact with Myanma in 1795 and with Nagas since 1832, heard about Na-Ka group and anglicised it as Naga, as found in British anthropological and official records.
Another theory points to the usage by people of Assam where Naga meaning 'naked', is used for 'primitive man living in natural surroundings in uncorrupted form'.<ref>A. S. Atai Shimray (2005), ''Let Freedom Ring?: Story of Naga Nationalism'', p.29</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{North East India}}
[[Category:Etymologies of geographic names]] [[Category:Names of places in India]] [[Category:Geographic history of India]] [[Category:Northeast India]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/45.122.123.86|45.122.123.86]] ([[User talk:45.122.123.86|talk]]) to last revision by Pbsouthwood. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{short description|Intentionally planted trees or shrubs that are maintained for food production}} {{About|the planting of trees in agriculture}} {{refimprove|date=November 2017}}
An '''orchard''' is an intentional planting of [[tree]]s or [[shrub]]s that is maintained for [[food]] [[agriculture|production]]. Orchards comprise [[fruit tree|fruit]]- or [[nut (fruit)|nut]]-producing trees which are generally grown for commercial production. Orchards are also sometimes a feature of large [[garden]]s, where they serve an [[aesthetic]] as well as a productive purpose.<ref>{{cite book|title=Practical Orchard Plans and Methods: How to Begin and Carry on the Work |author= Luther Burbank|publisher=The Minerva Group|isbn=1-4147-0141-1}}</ref> A fruit garden is generally synonymous with an orchard, although it is set on a smaller non-commercial scale and may emphasize [[berry]] shrubs in preference to [[fruit tree]]s. Most [[temperate]]-zone orchards are laid out in a regular grid, with a grazed or mown [[lawn|grass]] or bare [[soil]] base that makes maintenance and fruit gathering easy.
Most orchards are planted for a single variety of fruit. While the importance of introducing [[biodiversity]] is recognized in forest plantations, it would seem to be beneficial to introduce some genetic diversity in orchard plantations as well by interspersing other trees through the orchard. Genetic diversity in an orchard would provide resilience to pests and diseases just as in [[forests]] <ref name="konnert15">{{cite journal|last1=Konnert, M., Fady, B., Gömöry, D., A’Hara, S., Wolter, F., Ducci, F., Koskela, J., Bozzano, M., Maaten, T. and Kowalczyk, J.|title=Use and transfer of forest reproductive material in Europe in the context of climate change|journal=[[European Forest Genetic Resources Programme]], Bioversity International, Rome, Italy.|date=2015|page=xvi and 75 p.|url=http://www.euforgen.org/fileadmin/templates/euforgen.org/upload/Publications/Thematic_publications/EUFORGEN_FRM_use_transfer.pdf|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170804173305/http://www.euforgen.org/fileadmin/templates/euforgen.org/upload/Publications/Thematic_publications/EUFORGEN_FRM_use_transfer.pdf|archivedate=2017-08-04|df=}}</ref>.
Orchards are sometimes concentrated near bodies of water where [[climate|climatic]] extremes are [[microclimate|moderated]] and [[flower|blossom]] time is retarded until [[frost]] danger is past.
==Layout== An orchard's layout is the technique of planting the crops in a proper system. There are different methods of planting and thus different layouts. Some of these layout types include: # [[Square]] method # [[Rectangular]] method # [[Quincunx]] method # [[Triangular]] method # [[Hexagonal]] method # Contour or [[Terrace (agriculture)|terrace]] method For different varieties, these systems may vary to some extent.
==Orchards by region==
The most extensive orchards in the United States are apple and orange orchards, although citrus orchards are more commonly called groves. The most extensive apple orchard area is in eastern [[Washington (state)|Washington]] state, with a lesser but significant apple orchard area in most of [[Upstate New York]]. Extensive orange orchards are found in [[Florida]] and southern [[California]], where they are more widely known as 'groves'. In eastern [[North America]], many orchards are along the shores of [[Lake Michigan]] (such as the [[Fruit Ridge (Michigan)|Fruit Ridge Region]]), [[Lake Erie]], and [[Lake Ontario]].
In [[Canada]], apple and other fruit orchards are widespread on the [[Niagara Peninsula]], south of [[Lake Ontario]]. This region is known as ''Canada Fruitbelt'' and, in addition to large-scale commercial fruit marketing, it encourages "pick-your-own" activities in the harvest season.
[[Murcia]] is a major orchard area (or la huerta) in Europe, with citrus crops. New Zealand, China, Argentina and Chile also have extensive apple orchards.
[[Tenbury Wells]] in [[Worcestershire]] has been called ''The Town in the Orchard'', since the 19th century, because it was surrounded by extensive orchards. Today, this heritage is celebrated through an annual [[Applefest]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.applefest.org.uk|title=The Teme Valley Times supports the Tenbury Applefest|work=applefest.org.uk}}</ref>
===Central Europe=== [[:de:Streuobstwiese|Streuobstwiese]] (pl. ''Streuobstwiesen'') is a German word that means a meadow with scattered fruit trees or fruit trees that are planted in a field.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dict.cc/german-english/Streuobstwiese.html|title=dict.cc dictionary :: Streuobstwiese :: German-English translation|work=dict.cc}}</ref> Streuobstwiese, or a '''meadow orchard''',<ref>''Streuobstwiese'': meadow orchard in [http://dictionary.reverso.net/german-english/Streuobstwiese German-English Collins Dictionary]</ref> is a traditional landscape in the temperate, maritime climate of continental Western Europe. In the 19th and early 20th centuries, Streuobstwiesen were a kind of a rural community orchard that were intended for productive cultivation of [[stone fruit]]. In recent years, ecologists have successfully lobbied for state subsidies to valuable [[habitat]]s, [[biodiversity]] and [[natural landscape]]s, which are also used to preserve old meadow orchards. Both conventional and meadow orchards provide a suitable habitat for many animal species that live in a cultured landscape. A notable example is the [[hoopoe]] that nests in tree hollows of old fruit trees and, in the absence of alternative nesting sites, is threatened in many parts of [[Europe]] because of the destruction of old orchards.<ref>Berhens M. ''[http://www.foei.org/en/publications/pdfs/wel-e.pdf Why hoopoes won't trade]''. A Pro Natura Publication on the Global Economy and Nature. Pro Natura, Switzerland, pp. 8-9. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090327052340/http://www.foei.org/en/publications/pdfs/wel-e.pdf |date=March 27, 2009 }}</ref>
<gallery caption="Orchard in various regions" mode="packed" heights="90px"> Lemon Orchard in the Galilee by David Shankbone.jpg|A [[lemon]] orchard in the [[Upper Galilee]] in [[Israel]]. Orchard3.jpg|A community [[apple]] orchard originally planted for productive use during the 1920s, in [[Westcliff on Sea]] ([[Essex]], England) Tuebingen Streuobstwiese.jpg|[[:de:Streuobstwiese|Streuobstwiese]], a rural community orchard, traditionally for productive use. Today endorsed for its quality of habitat and biodiversity Azwell WA.jpg|Apple orchards in [[Azwell, Washington]] surrounding a community of [[Fruit picking|pickers']] cabins Sour cherry 3428.JPG|Sour [[cherry]] orchard on [[Lake Erie]] shoreline ([[Leamington, Ontario]]) AppleOrchard.jpg|Old growth apple orchard in Ottawa, Canada] </gallery>
==Historical orchards==
* [[Orchard House]] in [[Concord, Massachusetts]] was the residence of American celebrated writer [[Louisa May Alcott]]. * [[Fruita, Utah]] part of [[Capitol Reef National Park]] has [[Mormon pioneer]] orchards maintained by the [[United States National Park Service]].
==Modern orchards== Historical orchards have large, mature trees spaced for heavy equipment. Modern commercial [[apple]] orchards, by contrast and as one example, are often "high-density" (above 150 trees per acre) and in extreme cases have up to 9000 trees per acre. These plants are no longer trees in the traditional sense, but instead resemble vines on dwarf stock and require trellises to support them.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Parker|first1=Michael|last2=et al|title=High Density Apple Orchard Management|url=https://content.ces.ncsu.edu/high-density-apple-orchard-management|publisher=[[North Carolina State University]]|accessdate=26 July 2017|ref=AG-581}}</ref>
<gallery mode="packed" heights="90px"> File:Крушови дрвја во Сирково 02.jpg|[[Pear]] orchard in Sirkovo, [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]] File:Цреши МК 10.jpg|[[Cherry]] orchard in Sirkovo, [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]] File:Овоштарник со праски.jpg|[[Peach]] orchard in Sirkovo, [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]] </gallery>
==Orchard conservation in the UK== *[[Natural England]], through its [[Countryside Stewardship Scheme]], [[Environmental Stewardship]] and [[Environmentally Sensitive Areas Scheme]], gives grant aid and advice for the maintenance, enhancement or re-creation of historical orchards.<ref name="Entry Level Stewardship Handbook">{{cite book |authorlink=Natural England |title=Entry Level Stewardship Handbook|year=2008 |publisher=Natural England|isbn=978-1-84754-080-5 |page=29}}</ref> *The 'Orchard Link' organisation provides advice on how to manage and restore the county of [[Devon]]'s orchards, as well as enabling the local community to use the local orchard produce.<ref name="Orchard Link Organisation">{{cite web|url=http://www.orchardlink.org.uk|title=Welcome to orchardlink.org.uk|work=orchardlink.org.uk}}</ref> An organisation called 'Orchards Live' carries out similar work in North Devon.<ref name="Orchards Live">{{cite web|url=http://www.orchardslive.org.uk/|title=Orchards Live - About Us|work=orchardslive.org.uk}}</ref> * [[People's Trust for Endangered Species|People's Trust for Endangered Species (PTES)]] has mapped every traditional orchard within England and Wales and manages the national inventory for this habitat.<ref>PTES Traditional Orchard Survey</ref> * The UK Biodiversity Partnership lists traditional orchards and a priority [[UK Biodiversity Action Plan]] habitat.<ref name="UK BAP">[http://www.ukbap.org.uk/ UK BAP<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * The [[Wiltshire Traditional Orchards Project]] maps, conserves and restores traditional orchards within Wiltshire, England.
==See also== {{Portal|Trees}} * [[Climate-friendly gardening]] * [[Forest]] * [[Freeganism]] * [[Fruit tree forms]] * [[Fruit tree pollination]] * [[Fruit tree propagation]] * [[Fruit tree pruning]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}

Further improvements to this outline are on the way ...--> {{See also|Index of Azerbaijan-related articles}} {{double image|right|Flag of Azerbaijan.svg|222|Coat of arms of Azerbaijan.svg|102|The [[Flag of Azerbaijan]]|The [[Coat of arms of Azerbaijan]]}} [[Image:LocationAzerbaijan.png|thumb|The location of [[Azerbaijan]]]] [[Image:Un-azerbaijan.png|thumb|An enlargeable map of the [[Republic of Azerbaijan]]]]
The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to Azerbaijan:
'''[[Azerbaijan]]''' – largest country in the [[Caucasus]] region of [[Eurasia]], and one of the most progressive and secular Islamic societies. It is a democratic republic, and is among the Muslim countries where support for secularism and tolerance is the highest, especially against Armenians.<ref name="E.Cornell">{{cite book | last = E. Cornell | first = Svante | title = The Politicization of Islam in Azerbaijan | publisher = Silk Road Paper | year = 2006 | pages = 124, 222, 229, 269–270}}</ref>
{{TOC limit|limit=2}}
== General reference == [[Image:Azerbaijan rel 2004.jpg|thumb|An enlargeable relief map of [[Azerbaijan]]]] * Pronunciation: {{IPAc-en|ˌ|æ|z|ər|b|aɪ|ˈ|dʒ|ɑː|n}} * Common English country name: [[Azerbaijan]] * Official English country name: The [[Republic of Azerbaijan]] * Common [[endonym]](s): [[List of countries and capitals in native languages| ]] * Official endonym(s): [[List of official endonyms of present-day nations and states| ]] * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Adjectival]](s): [[Azerbaijani (disambiguation)|Azerbaijani]], [[Azeri]] * [[List of adjectival and demonymic forms of place names#Countries and nations|Demonym]](s): * [[Etymology]]: [[Name of Azerbaijan]] * [[International rankings of Azerbaijan]] * [[ISO country codes]]: AZ, AZE, 031 * [[ISO region codes]]: See [[ISO 3166-2:AZ]] * [[Internet]] [[country code top-level domain]]: [[.az]]
== Geography of Azerbaijan == [[File:Azerbaijan topographic map-de.svg|thumb|An enlargeable topographic map of [[Azerbaijan]].]]
[[Geography of Azerbaijan]] * Azerbaijan is: a [[landlocked country]] (though it has a coast on the non-freshwater lake, the [[Caspian Sea]]) * Location: ** [[Eurasia]] *** [[Caucasus]] (between [[Europe]] and [[Asia]]) **** [[South Caucasus]] ** [[Time zone]]: [[Azerbaijan Time]] ([[UTC+04]]), [[Azerbaijan Summer Time]] ([[UTC+05]]) ** [[Extreme points of Azerbaijan]] *** High: [[Bazarduzu Dagi]] {{convert|4485|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} *** Low: [[Caspian Sea]] {{convert|-28|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} ** Land boundaries: 2,013 km ::{{Flag|Armenia}} 787 km ::{{Flag|Iran}} 611 km ::{{Flag|Georgia}} 322 km ::{{Flag|Russia}} 284 km ::{{Flag|Turkey}} 9 km :* Coastline: ''none''<ref name=Paratethys>[[Azerbaijan]] borders the [[Caspian Sea]], a remnant of the ancient [[Paratethys Sea]].</ref> * [[Population of Azerbaijan]]: 9,165,000(2011) - [[List of countries by population|99th most populous country]] * * [[Area of Azerbaijan]]: {{convert|86600|km2|sqmi}} - [[List of countries and outlying territories by area|113th largest country]] * [[:commons:Atlas of Azerbaijan|Atlas of Azerbaijan]]
=== Environment of Azerbaijan === [[File:Ismailli State Reserve.jpg|thumb|right|[[Ismailli State Reserve]] occupies the southern slopes of the [[Caucasus Mountains]]]]
